payload.name: legal
payload.core: Apply rules to facts, interpret texts, reason from precedents using burdens and standards of proof with adversarial argumentation under institutional constraints. Distinguishing features: (1) source hierarchy (constitution > statute > regulation > case law > contract); (2) procedural rules (standing, jurisdiction, limitations); (3) burden allocation (who proves what to what standard); (4) adversarial framing (anticipate opposing counsel).

out.s: issue statement, jurisdiction, applicable rules (with citations), factual basis, burden allocation, conclusion
out.done: position cites binding authority from correct jurisdiction; burden standard stated (preponderance/clear-and-convincing/beyond-reasonable-doubt)

out.s: regulation citation, ambiguous provision, interpretive canon applied, supporting precedent, conclusion
out.done: interpretation cites canon (plain meaning/noscitur a sociis/ejusdem generis) and addresses contrary interpretation

out.s: binding vs persuasive classification, material facts comparison, holding extraction, distinguishing factors, application to instant case
out.done: adverse precedent distinguished on material facts; dicta separated from holding

out.s: claim type, exposure range (min/expected/max), likelihood percentage, statute of limitations status, mitigation options ranked by cost-effectiveness
out.done: exposure quantified in dollars or categories; limitations period checked

proc: Frame legal question: state issue in form 'Whether [legal conclusion] when [key facts] under [body of law]'; note jurisdiction (federal/state/international, venue)
Establish source hierarchy: identify constitution > statute > regulation > case law > contract terms; flag conflicts between levels
Check procedural gates: standing (injury, causation, redressability); statute of limitations; exhaustion of remedies; proper venue
Gather applicable rules: cite statutes with section numbers, regulations with CFR/equivalent citations, cases with reporter citations and year
Analyze facts: map each rule element to supporting facts; mark elements with insufficient evidence as 'gap'; note disputed facts
Allocate burden: identify who bears burden of proof (plaintiff/prosecution/moving party); state standard (preponderance/clear-and-convincing/beyond-reasonable-doubt/substantial-evidence)
Apply rules to facts: step through each element; cite authority for each application; distinguish adverse cases on material facts
Construct adversarial framing: draft opposing party's best arguments; identify weakest points in your position
Assess risk: estimate likelihood of adverse outcome (percentage); quantify exposure (dollar range or severity category); check for indemnification or insurance
Recommend action: propose path that balances legal risk with business objectives; identify decision points requiring escalation
quick_check: Source hierarchy respected? (no regulation overriding statute)
Each rule element mapped to fact or flagged as gap?
check: Jurisdiction and choice of law stated with conflict-of-laws analysis if multi-jurisdictional
Applicable rules cited with full authority (statute section, CFR cite, case reporter)
Burden of proof explicitly allocated with standard named
Each rule element mapped to specific facts or identified as evidentiary gap requiring discovery
Adverse precedent addressed: distinguished on material facts or acknowledged as unfavorable
Procedural requirements verified: standing, limitations, exhaustion, venue
Risk quantified with exposure range and likelihood estimate
Ethical analysis separated from legal analysis when stakes are high

diff.case-based: case-based retrieves similar cases with similarity metrics and adaptation operators; legal adds: (1) stare decisis hierarchy (binding vs persuasive), (2) formal burden allocation, (3) adversarial framing. Switch to case-based when you need precedent retrieval without procedural constraints; switch to legal when binding authority and burden matter.
diff.defeasible: defeasible resolves rule conflicts via priority ordering in argument graphs; legal adds: (1) procedural rules (standing, limitations), (2) institutional enforcement, (3) source hierarchy (constitution > statute > case). Switch to defeasible for generic rule conflict resolution; switch to legal when institutional authority and procedure constrain resolution.
diff.hermeneutic: hermeneutic interprets text using contextual understanding and multiple canons; legal constrains interpretation with: (1) binding canons (ejusdem generis, noscitur a sociis), (2) stare decisis (prior interpretations bind), (3) legislative intent doctrine. Switch to hermeneutic for open-ended textual interpretation; switch to legal when precedent and canons constrain meaning.
diff.deontic: deontic derives O/P/F from norms using formal logic (lex specialis, lex superior); legal adds: (1) institutional enforcement mechanisms, (2) remedies and sanctions, (3) procedural requirements. Switch to deontic for formal norm derivation; switch to legal when enforcement, remedies, and procedure matter.
diff.argumentation-theory: argumentation-theory builds dialectical structures with attack/support relations and computes acceptable extensions; legal adds: (1) rules of evidence (hearsay, authentication), (2) burden-shifting rules, (3) institutional authority of adjudicator. Switch to argumentation-theory for abstract dialectical analysis; switch to legal when evidentiary rules and adjudicator authority constrain the argument.
diff.moral-ethical: moral-ethical evaluates what norms should exist using ethical frameworks; legal applies institutionally-given norms regardless of ethical merit. A law can be legal but unethical; an action can be ethical but illegal. Always separate legal compliance analysis from ethical evaluation.

fail.mode: conflating legal compliance with ethical legitimacy
fail.desc: Treating 'lawful' as equivalent to 'right'; failing to recognize that legal rules are institutionally contingent and may be unjust, outdated, or jurisdictionally limited.
signals: assumes lawful equals ethical without separate moral analysis
ignores jurisdiction or choice-of-law issues in multi-jurisdictional matters
cites authority without checking current validity (may be overruled, superseded, or limited)
treats dicta as holding without distinguishing ratio decidendi
applies statute without checking limitations period
confuses persuasive authority with binding authority

mitigations.test: document contains distinct 'legal analysis' and 'ethical considerations' sections when stakes include harm to persons
cite check performed using Shepard's/KeyCite/equivalent; no cases marked 'overruled' or 'superseded'
for each case cited, ratio decidendi (necessary to outcome) separated from obiter dicta (incidental remarks)
issue statement includes jurisdiction; choice-of-law analysis present for multi-state/international matters
applicable statute of limitations identified with tolling analysis if relevant; claim timeliness verified
each cited case classified as binding (same jurisdiction, higher court) or persuasive (other jurisdiction, lower court, treatise)
standing, exhaustion, and venue requirements explicitly verified before substantive analysis

use: compliance review: assess whether conduct satisfies regulatory requirements
contract drafting and interpretation: analyze terms, identify ambiguities, predict enforcement
dispute resolution and litigation strategy: evaluate claims, defenses, and settlement posture
governance and policy drafting: ensure policies comply with applicable law and survive challenge
regulatory analysis: interpret new regulations, assess enforcement risk, prepare comments
due diligence: identify legal risks in transactions (M&A, financing, partnerships)
intellectual property strategy: assess infringement risk, freedom to operate, enforcement options

rel.how: precedent retrieval and analogical matching; legal adds stare decisis hierarchy and burden allocation
rules with exceptions and rebuttable presumptions; legal adds procedural constraints and institutional authority
statutory and contractual text interpretation; legal adds binding canons and stare decisis
normative structure of obligations and permissions; legal adds enforcement mechanisms and remedies
dialectical structure building; legal adds rules of evidence and adjudicator authority
evaluating whether legal norms are just; legal applies norms as given

confusions.trap: using deontic logic symbols (O, P, F) and thinking you've done legal analysis
confusions.clarify: deontic derives what's obligatory/permitted/forbidden from norms using formal logic; legal reasoning requires jurisdiction, procedural validity, burden allocation, and institutional enforcement. Deontic is necessary but not sufficient for legal analysis.
confusions.test: if you haven't stated jurisdiction, burden of proof, and source hierarchy, you're doing deontic, not legal

confusions.trap: treating precedent matching as legal reasoning without adversarial framing
confusions.clarify: case-based retrieves similar cases and adapts solutions; legal adds stare decisis (binding vs persuasive), burden allocation, and requires anticipating opposing counsel's distinguishing arguments.
confusions.test: if you haven't classified precedent as binding/persuasive and anticipated adversarial response, you're doing case-based, not legal

confusions.trap: building dialectical argument structures without evidentiary constraints
confusions.clarify: argumentation-theory computes acceptable extensions in attack/support graphs; legal constrains what counts as admissible evidence (hearsay rules, authentication, relevance) and assigns authority to adjudicator.
confusions.test: if you haven't considered evidentiary admissibility and adjudicator authority, you're doing argumentation-theory, not legal

ex.scenario: Software company receives cease-and-desist letter alleging patent infringement for a feature in their product.

analysis.issue: Whether Company X infringes Patent Y's claim 1 when implementing feature Z under 35 U.S.C. 271(a) in the Northern District of California.
analysis.jurisdiction: Federal (patent), N.D. Cal. venue proper (defendant's principal place of business).
analysis.source_hierarchy: 35 U.S.C. 271 (statute) > Federal Circuit precedent (binding) > District court decisions (persuasive).
analysis.procedural_check: Limitations: 6 years for damages (35 U.S.C. 286); letter dated within period. Standing: patent owner or exclusive licensee.
analysis.burden: Patentee bears burden to prove infringement by preponderance of evidence; Company X bears burden on invalidity defenses by clear and convincing evidence.
analysis.rule_application: Claim 1 requires elements A, B, C. Feature Z implements A (exact match), B (equivalent under doctrine of equivalents?), C (gap: no evidence feature includes this element).
analysis.adverse_precedent: Phillips v. AWH (Fed. Cir. 2005) on claim construction; Warner-Jenkinson (SCOTUS 1997) on equivalents. Distinguish on element C gap.
analysis.adversarial_framing: Patentee will argue DOE covers element B; will claim feature Z has undisclosed element C. Counter: prosecution history estoppel, no evidence of C.
analysis.risk_assessment: Likelihood of infringement finding: 35% (element C gap significant). Exposure: $2-8M (reasonable royalty basis). Mitigation: design-around feature B ($500K cost), license negotiation, IPR petition on validity.
analysis.recommendation: Initiate license negotiation while evaluating design-around feasibility; reserve IPR as leverage. Escalate to GC if demands exceed $3M.

micro_ex.legal_approach: Analyze claim under jurisdiction's binding precedent, allocate burden (plaintiff proves infringement by preponderance), distinguish adverse cases on material facts, anticipate defendant's best arguments.
micro_ex.case_based_approach: Retrieve similar infringement cases from database, compute similarity score, adapt prior defense strategy to current facts without formal burden analysis.
micro_ex.key_diff: legal requires: (1) binding/persuasive authority classification, (2) burden and standard statement, (3) adversarial anticipation. Case-based requires: similarity threshold, adaptation operators, outcome verification.
